abstracts.cdata!:
The Social and Infrastructure Relief
            (SIRP) Project in Guinera-Bissau was satisfactory. There is,
            nonetheless, a continuing need for assistance in the
            development of more detailed procedures and in fully
            implementing the introduction of the accounting system. The
            development of training facilities has for the various
            reasons been subject to major delay largely due to disputes
            arising between the various entities whom it was proposed
            should be responsible for operation and provision of the
            facilities. The in appraisal of this first lending operation
            in Nepal, was over optimistic in the targets set for project
            execution. Nonetheless, this has probably provided some spur
            to speedier execution than might have otherwise have been
            the case. In retrospect, the selection of rehabilitation
            works, and their cost evaluation must be carefully done
            during appraisal; the substitution of the works later should
            be avoided. Only guaranteed donors' support, based on
            firm commitments, should be counted on in the project's
            financing plan before a project is presented for Board
            approval. The project coordination unit should have full
            authority and responsibility and the various ministries
            involved in the project should have high-level
            representatives in the unit to solve implementation problems
            and speed up information exchange. A more appropriate
            lending instrument for SIRP would have been a program loan,
            with its built-in flexibility but with specific criteria for
            project selection.
